intro: Dendrophthoe pulverulenta, commonly known as the dusty mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees. It lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients through its stems, which are embedded into the host's bark. The plant produces small, white or pale green leaves and clusters of small, inconspicuous flowers. It is typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, often growing on hardwood trees. Its unique parasitic nature and delicate appearance make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
